title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" may be cited as the short title. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be treated as valid for voting purposes. The Attorney General can take legal action for disparities in voting opportunities. The Attorney General can take legal action to address disparities in in-person voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members. This includes increasing the availability of polling places. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over such actions, heard by a court of three judges, with appeals to the Supreme Court. The judges must expedite the case. The Attorney General can address disparities in voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members by taking legal action. An aggrieved person can bring an action to challenge such disparities, with provisions for expedited proceedings. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Protections Relating to Indian Reservations under Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include requirements for approval before eliminating or moving polling places on Indian reservations. Protections under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for Indian reservations include restrictions on moving or consolidating polling places across natural boundaries, eliminating in-person voting, reducing early voting opportunities, and changing voting location hours on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 protects Indian reservations by prohibiting changes to polling places, in-person voting, early voting, and voting hours on reservations. Amendments include defining "Indian reservation" and expanding the Act's scope to cover new activities. SEC. 4. FEDERAL ELECTION OVERSIGHT ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if there are complaints of voter suppression based on race or color. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations in cases of voter suppression based on race or color. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions for ending observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8 after the next general election for President. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 amends definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, as well as the definition of a member of an Indian tribe. SEC. 7 amends bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to make reports of Federal election observers publicly available. SEC. 9 addresses tribal voting consultation. SEC. 9 requires the Attorney General to consult annually with tribal organizations on voting issues for members of Indian tribes.
